title: Why so few Love Island couples survive after leaving their idyllic villa life
text:

So few Love Island couples have survived beyond the villa.

While there are a few success stories to come out of the hit ITV2 dating show, there are way more relationships that have ended in heartbreak and tears.

Alex and Olivia Bowen, from series two, have entered wedded bliss, as have their series co-stars Cara De La Hoyde and Nathan Massey, who also have a child together.

Jess and Dom Lever, from series three, also recently tied the knot and welcomed a baby together.

And there are another handful of couples from across the years who are still going strong.

(Image: Emma Smith)

(Image: Ken McKay/ITV/REX/Shutterstock)

But way more couples have shocked fans by splitting, like series four winners Jack Fincham and Dani Dyer , series three champs Kem Cetinay and Amber Davies, their pal Chris Hughes and Olivia Attwood , and series four's Wes Nelson an Megan Barton-Hanson.

Even the winning couple from this year's series, Amber Gill and Greg O'Shea, only lasted a few weeks in the outside world.

Some couples have split within weeks or even days of leaving the villa, while most manage a few months - and even their own spin-off shows - before going their separate ways.

So why do so few manage to stand the test of time?

(Image: Instagram)

(Image: ITV/REX/Shutterstock)

A relationship expert from dating website Badoo told Mirror Online that there are way too many influences and distractions once people return to the real world.

They said: "The villa is so different to normal life, feelings are intensified as you are dealing with being filmed, new people, close proximity and being away from friends and family who might reign you in.

"So, when you go back to 'normality', you might see, sense or realise that this person is not going to fit in with your friends/way of life. They also might not live close to you in real life so having a long-distance relationship puts strain on the relationship."

(Image: Getty)

(Image: REX)

Our expert added: "Things will definitely seem less romantic once leaving the idyllic setting too (i.e. goodbye sun and relaxation and hello English weather and being very busy with the fame aftermath).

"The programme is set up to give people fame, popularity and Instagram followers. There is less emphasis on purely finding a partner than there might have been in the early days of the show."
